hobby.message: Any new mods on your FPV quad?
What's your last origami fold say?
Typewriters treating you better than people?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Just wanted something quiet after the shift.
I fold paper sometimes. Keeps my mind steady.
Hard to focus lately with everything happening.
Paper birds don’t come out right when sirens keep going.
Long day up at the Directorate, needed a change of scene.
When I’m home, I usually make origami—cranes, mostly.
Used some old reports last night to fold, not ideal paper.
Protests outside made it tricky to concentrate.
Feels strange making something peaceful out of old warnings.
Things feel unstable. I come here to clear my head.
My hobby’s origami—complex models, not the simple stuff.
It’s mostly cranes, but sometimes tessellations if I have better paper.
Lately, I’ve been using discarded BCI printouts for folding.
After the dossier leak, even small routines get interrupted.
Can’t help noticing the codes on the paper when I fold.
Just needed a break from the Directorate chaos and—well, the city right now.
Origami’s mine. Not just cranes, but modular pieces if I find time.
I always look for scrap paper—system reports mostly. Weird habit.
Yesterday, folding felt impossible, sirens blaring, power flickering after the protests.
Used to be calming, now the codes and warnings on the paper get to me.
Sometimes I think the system’s even in my hobby.
Had to stop, just sat staring at unfinished shapes for an hour.
The system’s been off-kilter since Halden died. Everything’s out of sync.
I started origami as a way to quiet my mind—tiny patterns, precision, control.
Now I fold with Directorate castoffs—flagged reports, system warnings, BCI anomaly lists.
After the dossier scandal, folding feels different—like I’m shaping pieces of the collapse.
Last night, power flickered, sirens everywhere, wings kept folding the wrong way.
It’s unsettling, seeing someone’s flagged status turn into a paper bird.
Feels like the world won’t let go, even when I try to make something simple.
Some nights I keep the cranes just to remind myself how fragile things are.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Folded a few last week, nothing special.
Just old office paper left now. Not great for precision.
Hard to concentrate lately with everything outside.
Maybe it's not the time for delicate things.
Noise travels too far right now.
Yes, made some cranes yesterday from system printouts.
Not ideal, but real origami paper's hard to get.
Kept seeing warning codes in the folds.
Been harder to relax since the protests started.
Makes you think twice about what's private.
Authorities notice even tiny details lately.
I did. Used flagged incident sheets—only paper available after the lockdown.
My folds weren’t right. Too many interruptions from the street noise.
It’s meant to calm me, but the sirens mess with my focus.
Sometimes the patterns look like BCI scores—hard to ignore what’s happening.
After the dossier leaks, everything feels tangled, even simple things.
Hard to lose yourself in a hobby when the city’s boiling outside.
Still, I keep folding. Habit, I guess.
Plenty of cranes, though lately, the paper’s all Council briefings. Strange, right?
After the leaks, all the good paper is locked down.
I never thought I’d fold a missing persons roster but here we are.
Every crease reminds me the system even reaches here.
Last night, I heard the protests and just folded until the lights cut out.
Guess hobbies don’t protect you from anything anymore.
Lately, the origami looks more like stress relief, less like art.
Almost stopped when the power flickered again, but I kept going.
Yeah… lots of cranes. I started when I felt myself unraveling at work.
Now, I use whatever I find—Council warnings, missing persons lists. It’s unsettling.
After the protests and communication blackout, real origami paper is impossible to get.
Last week, a substation near my block was hit. The blackout startled me mid-fold.
I watched system error alerts in the candlelight, folding anyway.
It’s strange—the BCI flags even details on my hobby, like I don’t own it anymore.
Still, I need the precision, the repetition. Origami’s always been my quiet protest.
Some days, even as everything falls apart, I line the paper cranes on the sill.
Feels like my own small order inside all this chaos.
